title: Mindscape Ask Me Anything, Sean Carroll | May 2025

rawLines.text: Hello everyone. Welcome to the May 2025
Ask Me Anything edition of the Mindscape
Podcast. I'm your host Sean Carroll. I
thought that today for this month's AMA,
we would start off with some good news.
A tiny piece of good news, a little
miniature carving of good news in a
world that has plenty of largecale bad
news going on. But, you know, you have
to look for those good little things.
The good news is that Puck has been
adopted. He has found his forever home.
Previous listeners of Mindscape AMAs
will know that Puck is our stray cat. We
have the permanent cats, Ariel and
Caliban, uh, who Patreon supporters are
are well acquainted with. Puck was, uh,
someone who showed up on our back porch
a year and a half ago, and we fed him
and nurtured him and sheltered him as an
outdoor cat, built a little cat door so
we could come into the basement. But at
some point, we said, "Look, we got to
get this kitty um fixed. We got to get
him shots, make sure he's okay." Okay.
So, we trapped him, took him to the vet,
and as soon as he came inside, he fell
in love with the idea of being an indoor
cat. He was clearly luxury oriented. He
loved the soft blankets and the cat
towers and all that. Had no interest
whatsoever in going back outside, which
was our original plan. Sadly, he uh does
not get along with other cats. And we
have prior residents here, Ariel and
Caliban, who get priority. And so if
Puck can't get along with our cats, then
he can't stay with us. So we've been
looking for a new home for him. The good
news is that despite his original
spiciness and sharp edges, it turns out
that he is the most affectionate cat in
the world. He just wants to be with
human beings and curl up with you and
purr all the time once he gets to know
you. So we thought he would be a really
good fit to someone who was mostly home
and could just be with him and take care
of him. And so we found such a person.
And the good news, even better news I
should say, is that that person is a
Mindscape listener. Terren, who lives in
New York City, um, actually was friends
with someone who is another Johns
Hopkins professor who I knew. So, she
made the introduction and Terrence came
down to visit. We had a sit down with
Puck and we talked about it and they all
got along very well. And so, uh, I, uh,
was going up to a conference in New
Jersey anyway just this week, a
conference in honor of the retirement of
Barry Lower, previous Mindscape guest,
and a bunch of other Mindscape previous
guests were there at the conference. And
I took Puck with me and just drove him
up to New York and uh, dropped him off
at Terren's place, and they seem to once
again get along great. And I think it's
going to be a wonderful, wonderful fit.
And Puck is now a New York kitty cat. Um
he's very very adaptable. He abides with
whatever situation he's in. He didn't
even mind the drive up even though he'd
never been in a long car ride before. So
um I'm very very happy with how things
have worked out. I will um I'm sure
there'll be future updates on various
kitty cats throughout. Most most
mindscape uh talk is not about cats, but
there's got to be a little bit of talk
about cats because it's good news in a
world where other things are going
badly. With that, we can get into the
AMA proper. Of course, remember that the
questions for the Ask Me Anything
episodes are asked by Patreon
supporters. Uh, it's really easy to be a
Patreon supporter. You know, it's
there's a barrier. There's sort of a
potential barrier, physicists would say,
to like signing up with Patreon and
putting your numbers in or whatever, but
it's easier than it looks. And once
you're there, you can support creators
of all sorts, including the Mindscape
podcast. So, just go to patreon.com
uh
sorryanmcarol m for my middle initial
Michael and uh then you can pledge to
support Mindscape and you get ad free
versions of the podcast. You get to ask
questions for the AMAs and also for
every episode I do a little short
reflection um audio that I share with
Patreon supporters. So, it's worth doing
if only to feel like you're supporting
something that um provides hours of
entertainment here at Mindscape in
various ways. And speaking of which,
let's go.
[Music]
Anonymous asks, "Are there any sci-fi
tropes or prevalent physics ideas in
general which you would place on an even
lower credence on being possible than
faster than light
communication?" Um, you know, I'm
actually, if you, if you know my talks,
my feelings about science fiction in
movies and films, uh, TV novels or
whatever, I'm pretty forgiving. I don't
have, you don't don't take great
pleasure in sitting and watching a movie
and picking apart the scientific
inaccuracies. Uh, what I care about is
whether or not it throws you out of the
movie. Whether you go like, "No, that's
not what would happen." So, I don't mind
faster and light communication or travel
in a science fiction movie. It's clear
why they're doing it. It makes the
rhythm and the time scales of the story
that they're telling be more similar to
the rhythm and time scales of
earth-based stories. battles in um on
land or on the sea or whatever are more
similar to space battles if you can go
faster than the speed of light because
you can get places more quickly. So, I
don't I don't mind that. But, of course,
you know, there's always also something
pleasurable to be gleaned from a good
story that doesn't violate the laws of
physics just to tell a more familiar
story. Um, and that's worth doing. So
the the things that I that bug me are
not like oh that would really never
happen so much as this is just lazy and
they always do it and they don't even
question it and it's not realistic. And
the example that comes to mind, it
doesn't bother a lot of people but it
bothers me is just that in almost every
science fiction space opera kind of film
they say well we have artificial gravity
on our spaceships. So life on the
Millennium Falcon or Battlestar
Galactica or whatever is not that
different than life on Earth or on a
battleship here on the oceans. You're
still pulled down toward the floor. And
I think number one, there's actually not
any way to do that in terms of the laws
of physics. You can create the illusion
of artificial gravity by spinning a
ship. Um, but they they generally don't
do that because they want their ships to
sort of look sleek and aerodynamic even
though they're moving through space. And
then there isn't really any way in the
known laws of physics to artificially
pull things in some arbitrary direction
just to give human beings a comfortable
feeling that there's a floor beneath
their feet. It's not something that gets
in the way of storytelling in any way.
In fact, it makes the storytelling much
easier. It certainly makes it more
intuitive and recognizable for the
viewer of the movie to see people
standing up with gravity pulling them
toward the ground, but it's just
universal and just such an obvious
cheat. You know, there's it's not what
would really happen in in the actual
science fiction. So, I would I would
respect a version of a space opera kind
of story that didn't make use of that
lazy trope of artificial gravity on the
spaceships. it would be much more
expensive and weird. Of course, there's
been science fiction movies set in the
solar system, for example, like Europa
Report or whatever, where um they don't
have artificial gravity. It tries to be
more grounded and realistic. You know,
generally, roughly speaking, if your
movie shows people flying through our
solar system, they try to be realistic
about artificial gravity. Once they're
out in interstellar space, they say,
"Forget that. That's too much effort."
And not only on the ships, right? but
between the ships like everyone has a
common orientation in space. There's
it's like there's up and down in space
or something like that. That's not what
it would be like. So, it's not, you
know, entirely a violation of the laws
of physics because you can imagine
things. It's very, very hard to imagine
things, much harder than most people
think it is to imagine artificial
gravity. But that's the one thing that
sort of always rubs me the wrong way
just a little bit.
Now, I'm going to group three questions
together on a common theme. Rammy
Fishler says, "Do you use AI tools in
your professional life? If you do, which
AI tools do you use, and how do you use
them? For example, do you use AI to
solve equations?" Joseph Ellie or Eli
says, "Something I've realized in the
past month or so is how monumental AI is
as a learning tool in a way that it
feels like a lot of people are
underappreciating. Sure, AI can write
code and help you troubleshoot your
router, but if you're curious and know
how to ask good questions, you can learn
about literally anything you want at any
time. Perfectly tailored to your
attention span and current level of
understanding. This feels like it could
be the biggest cognitive phase
transition in human history. Am I being
too sensationalist about this or is it
really that big of a deal? And then
Yazison Alhajari says, "I'm fascinated
by the interplay between scientific and
artistic creativity. While the language
of the arts now seems disrupted by AI,
challenging our notions of human
creativity, I'm excited by the
opportunities this presents. By
automating mechanical routine tasks, AI
allows adaptive artists to focus on what
is truly creative. How do you see this
dynamic playing out in the sciences
which are inherently objective and not
personal? Can you share your thoughts on
how this might shape the future of
scientific
exploration? So, I think that I mean
maybe I could have ordered the questions
differently. I think that Joseph's
question in the middle there provides a
pretty good answer to the other two
questions, you know, about how AI can be
used. Um, I think AI is tremendously
useful when used in the right way. I
It's weird. I've said it many, many
times, but the current large language
models we have are intentionally tuned
to make you think you're talking to a
human agent, but you're not. And there's
obvious reasons why they want you to act
as if you are. But it also leads us to
sort of not use it in the most ideal
way. And I think that Joseph is
completely correct um to sort of answer
Ramy's question about how I use AI in my
professional life. By far the most
useful application that I have of it is
learning new things. And it's not, you
know, it it's helpful if you know enough
about the subject to ask good questions
about it. And then what you're doing is
filling in your gaps. Like when you
learn from a textbook, which I'm all in
favor of. I've written textbooks and I'm
writing another one. Um, you are faced
with the problem that the author of the
textbook has the job of anticipating
your confusions, right? What is it that
you think you understand and don't
quite? So, they have to sort of try to
say, well, you might think this, but
maybe that. Whereas with the AI, you can
just tell it what your confusions are.
are you're like I don't understand how
this leads to that or why they say this
or even things what I found it useful
for you know in mathematics for example
when people say well you know here's a
certain construction mathematically and
it it leads to this conclusion and often
there's sort of background knowledge
going on that I don't have if it's a an
area of mathematics that I'm not
completely familiar with and so there
are implications of this result that are
not immediately obvious to me but would
be obvious to someone who was embedded
in that area. And you can ask the AI,
you can ask the large language model. I
don't I don't have favorites or anything
like that. I use um GPT sometimes. I use
claude which is anthropics sometimes,
whatever. Um but you can say like okay,
why do I care about this result? What is
the implication? What is it useful for?
And it will tell you. Now, of course,
it's not always right, you know. Um you
can also ask it to just do a
calculation. I don't ever ask AIS to
solve equations because I mean that's
literally exactly the kind of thing
where I would want to be very sure it
didn't make mistakes and the AI will
always make mistakes. Not always, I
suppose, but it will frequently make
mistakes. And therefore, it's more
useful to use it in a in a situation
where it's sort of working hand inhand
with you, right? Where you are listening
to what AI says and then judging whether
it makes sense or not. Um, the idea just
having the AI write things for you
without even reading them. I mean,
people write science papers, have the AI
write science papers for them without
even reading them. You know, it's
perfectly obvious that they do that. And
that's just bizarre and crazy to me. But
I can ask an AI like I asked uh chat GPT
the other day, or not chat GPT, I guess.
I don't know. The labels on the
different AI models completely escape me
these days. But I asked um as a beam of
light comes from a distant galaxy to the
earth, it will travel through dark
matter um in the conventional cold dark
matter model in cosmology. Some of that
dark matter will be in the galaxy where
the light leaves. Some of it will be in
our galaxy where the light arrives. But
some of it will just be spread thinly
throughout intergalactic space in
between the voids. There's more distance
that the photon travels in the voids,
but there's a lower density of dark
matter. So, what wins? Does the photon
travel mostly through is most of the
column density of dark matter from the
local concentrations in galaxies and
clusters or is it mostly in the voids in
between? And it set up the calculation.
It says, "Oh, here's how to do it, and I
can look up these numbers." One major
leap forward that the most recent
versions of GPT have is that they can
site sources. And this has always been
my complaint because when AIs just make
things up, you don't know, right? And
it's much more helpful to be able to
look at a paper written by a human being
to verify where this idea comes from.
But uh now chat GPT or GPT whatever
whatever most recent model it is will
tell you will say okay go to this
archive paper and this is where I got
this idea from. that is enormously more
helpful. So anyway, I I don't
necessarily believe the answer that GPT
gave me, but it sets up a way to do the
calculation that I can check myself if I
want to. Then I can decide whether or
not I need to go into more detail,
whether or not I want to do it in a
different way. I can even ask it is
there a different way to do it, etc. So
in in that sense you know learning new
areas setting up calculations in certain
ways um also hugely helpful is just has
anyone thought about this before right
you know like I'm trying to do something
well has anyone else already done it I
was asking it about you know a model um
which might help to explain the Hubble
tension uh and I said which we talked
about with Adam Ree on the podcast quite
a while ago and with Mark Hamikowski
more recently.
And you know it could tell me well this
paper did this kind of thing which is
similar but not exactly the same right
hugely hugely useful because it's just
it knows a lot more stuff than I do.
It's not a replacement for human being
or human thought. So um to Ramy's
question that's how I use AI. To
Joseph's question yeah I think it's
hugely influential exactly in that way
of helping people learn things. Whether
it will be a true cognitive phase
transition, I'm not sure because I'm not
sure how many people are really devoted
to the idea of learning new things. For
those of us who are, it's very very
useful. And I think, you know, you see
that a lot of people just want to use it
to replace human cognition, which I
think is not the best use of it. Um, and
to Yison's question, yeah, I think
that scientists will get better at using
it, right? And it will again not replace
scientists, but um a scientist plus a
good AI handinand is better than a
scientist all by themselves. And that's
going to be very useful for science
going
forward. Jamie says, "The doomsday
argument suggests that statistically
you're likely to be born somewhere in
the middle of the total human
population, etc. Doesn't this and
related arguments about the state you
find yourself in, maybe including
anthropic reasoning and self-locating
uncertainty, subtly depend on some set
of subjectivity or consciousness
metaphysics? If we are just an
epipenomenal emergent property, then in
what sense do we find ourselves to be
here and now? Um, so I'm a little not
completely sure that I understand
exactly what you're getting at with this
question because there's many things
going on. I mean, there's details of
anthropic reasoning. Uh I mentioned on
the podcast before I think I did a whole

conventional anthropic reasoning is done

move in conventional anthropic reasoning
is to imagine that we are chosen

observers in the universe. I think
that's just not really true unless you

people exactly like me. Um, which is a
very tiny class compared to the general
people or general observers or whatever.
Um, so anyway, but I I don't I don't
think that's the question you're mostly
getting at. You're asking about
subjectivity or consciousness or
something like that. I don't think it
depends. Well, let's put it this way. In
my um consciousness metaphysics which is
entirely physicalist and emergentist I'm
saying that consciousness is just a way

of ordinary matter arranged in certain
configurations etc. Um so I see no
problem whatsoever in asking questions
like there are many such configurations
that are essentially identical to each
other scattered throughout the universe.
What is the chance that I'm any one of
them? What do most of them see when they
look outside? Things like that. I see no
problems with that at all. Um, you're
using words like consciousness and
observer, but they're just standins for

um, statements about configurations of
matter. There's nothing spooky about it
or anything like that. I guess if you
did have a spookier metaphysics, if you
thought that consciousness was something
over and above a certain collective
behavior of atoms arranged in a certain
way, then you might be troubled by
questions like in what sense do I find
myself to be here and now? Like where
else and when else could you find
yourself to be? And that's why it's hard
for me to answer this question. But
maybe if you thought there was some
ineffable essence of self that was
uniquely you and was different than the
other configurations of matter that were
naively similar to you, then maybe you
would have different questions about
that. But I think that for a general
physicalist who thought that
consciousness is emergent, this is not
really an issue.

my question about energy conservation in
the many worlds interpretation of

I'll it's worth mentioning again. It's

um one is the question of deriving the

you can just say well there's something

And the best we can do is assign a

anyway many different uh outcomes

if I have a spin that is a superp
position of spin up and spin down I

So where do the probabilities come from?
And again, I think there's an answer to

it is okay to worry that we are

that the probability is proportional to
the wave function squared. I think we do

very different way than what we're used

matter and energy rather than just

that oh look there's a classical limit
with matter and particles and things

you know making an assumption that it's

something more fundamental but that
doesn't mean that it's not uh uh work to

derivation Henry Jacobs says on idealism

So I completely agree that in many cases

there's just that super obvious reason

Hello everyone. Welcome to the May 2025 Ask Me Anything edition of the Mindscape Podcast. I'm your host Sean Carroll. The good news is that Puck has been adopted. He has found his forever home. Previous listeners of Mindscape AMAs will know that Puck is our stray cat. We have the permanent cats, Ariel and Caliban, uh, who Patreon supporters are well acquainted with. Puck was, uh, someone who showed up on our back porch a year and a half ago, and we fed him and nurtured him and sheltered him as an outdoor cat, built a little cat door so we could come into the basement. But at some point, we said, "Look, we got to get this kitty um fixed. We got to get him shots, make sure he's okay." Okay. So, we trapped him, took him to the vet, and as soon as he came inside, he fell in love with the idea of being an indoor cat. He was clearly luxury oriented. He loved the soft blankets and the cat towers and all that. Had no interest whatsoever in going back outside, which was our original plan. Sadly, he uh does not get along with other cats. And we have prior residents here, Ariel and Caliban, who get priority. And so if Puck can't get along with our cats, then he can't stay with us. So we've been looking for a new home for him. And the good news, even better news I should say, is that that person is a Mindscape listener. Terren, who lives in New York City, um, actually was friends with someone who is another Johns Hopkins professor who I knew. So, she made the introduction and Terrence came down to visit. And so, uh, I, uh, was going up to a conference in New Jersey anyway just this week, a conference in honor of the retirement of Barry Lower, previous Mindscape guest, and a bunch of other Mindscape previous guests were there at the conference. And I took Puck with me and just drove him up to New York and uh, dropped him off at Terren's place, and they seem to once again get along great. And I think it's going to be a wonderful, wonderful fit. And Puck is now a New York kitty cat. Um he's very very adaptable. He abides with whatever situation he's in. He didn't even mind the drive up even though he'd never been in a long car ride before. So um I'm very very happy with how things have worked out. I will um I'm sure there'll be future updates on various kitty cats throughout. Anonymous asks, "Are there any sci-fi tropes or prevalent physics ideas in general which you would place on an even lower credence on being possible than faster than light communication?" Um, you know, I'm actually, if you, if you know my talks, my feelings about science fiction in movies and films, uh, TV novels or whatever, I'm pretty forgiving. I don't have, you don't take great pleasure in sitting and watching a movie and picking apart the scientific inaccuracies. Uh, what I care about is whether or not it throws you out of the movie. Whether you go like, "No, that's not what would happen." So, I don't mind faster and light communication or travel in a science fiction movie. It's clear why they're doing it. It makes the rhythm and the time scales of the story that they're telling be more similar to the rhythm and time scales of earth-based stories. Battles in um on land or on the sea or whatever are more similar to space battles if you can go faster than the speed of light because you can get places more quickly. So, I don't I don't mind that. Um, and that's worth doing. So the the things that I that bug me are not like oh that would really never happen so much as this is just lazy and they always do it and they don't even question it and it's not realistic. So life on the Millennium Falcon or Battlestar Galactica or whatever is not that different than life on Earth or on a battleship here on the oceans. You're still pulled down toward the floor. And I think number one, there's actually not any way to do that in terms of the laws of physics. You can create the illusion of artificial gravity by spinning a ship. And then there isn't really any way in the known laws of physics to artificially pull things in some arbitrary direction just to give human beings a comfortable feeling that there's a floor beneath their feet. It's not something that gets in the way of storytelling in any way. In fact, it makes the storytelling much easier. You know, there's it's not what would really happen in in the actual science fiction. Of course, there's been science fiction movies set in the solar system, for example, like Europa Report or whatever, where um they don't have artificial gravity. You start with the fact that as the earth moves around the sun, uh, nearby stars shift slightly in their positions because of parallax, and that's just geometry. Um, so you can find the distances to nearby things, very nearby things, and these days we can do much better. So we can get a lot of real physical distances without any assumptions and, uh, in the galaxy you can find certain kinds of stars whose brightness you can calibrate. So it's not quite a standard candle, but it's a standardizable thing. It's not that all sephiids are the same brightness, but if I know the period, I know the brightness. And some sephiids are bright enough to see in other galaxies. So you can calibrate the distance to other galaxies. And then you can sometimes see supernova in those galaxies. And then if there there's different kinds of supernova, there's type ones, there's type twos, etc. And they have different light curves and different spectra. So you can tell them apart. They don't, they don't oscillate, but they have a period of increase in brightness and decrease in brightness that is correlated with their maximum brightness. So, they're standardizable candles. So the, the answer is we don't like know ahead of time the brightness of a certain supernova very far away, but, um, we can figure out the relative brightness of the supernova and a sephiid variable and the relative brightness of a far away sephiid and a nearby sephiid, and we can get the distance to that using just geometry in parallax, and that's how we build up the cosmic distance ladder. Gordell says, "You've discussed effective field theories, emphasizing the concept of an ultraviolet UV cutoff and how it prevents the details of very high energy physics from significantly affecting the physics at lower experimentally accessible energies.
In other words, physics above the UV cutoff doesn't causally influence phenomena at larger lower energy scales.
In cosmology, we simply similarly talk about horizons, boundaries beyond which regions of the universe cannot influence or interact with us.
Although we believe there is stuff beyond our observable horizon, it doesn't affect our local physics.
Is the notion of a UV cutoff analogous to or even mathematically equivalent to a cosmological horizon?
And if so, could that horizon itself possess some structure such as geometry or other physical properties?"
Uh, no is the short answer to this one.
Um, I kind of get the analogy that you're reaching for, but it doesn't really work for a few reasons.
One is the cosmological hor, I mean, there's, I guess there's one very big reason there.
There's sort of one reason that sounds good, but is wrong.
Namely, that is that is not really on point, I should say.
Namely, that the cosmological horizon is something that happens at large scales and the ultraviolet cutoff is something that happens at small scales.
Uh, so you wouldn't expect them to really be analogous in any simple way, and indeed they're not.
So it's not really true that in the spirit of effective field theories, high-energy things have no effect on low-energy things.
That's not really the point.
They do have an effect.
The point is just that the effect that they have can be summarized in an effective field theory.
That is to say, we can pick certain parameters for the low-energy infrared field theory, the field theory that describes low-mass, low-energy particles, um, and the effects that high-energy particles have on those low-energy particles are can be subsumed into shifting the parameters of the low-energy theory, the coupling constants, the masses, and so forth.
So the effects are absolutely there.
They're just easily summarized in a small number of parameters.
Whereas with a cosmological horizon, the effects are simply not there.
That's the thing about horizons.
You can't actually cross from one side of the horizon to the other, from the interior to the exterior anyway.
So if there's something beyond our cosmological horizon, it literally has no effect on what goes on inside.
That's a crucial difference between the two cases.

Wade Dunn says when you talk about cosmic inflation just after the big bang it seems to violate the speed limit of the universe. the speed of light what gives uh not when I talk about cosmic inflation you know as we were talking about before with the scale factor of the universe the scale factor is not a distance right the scale factor of the universe is a relative distance you know if I have a galaxy and I talk I can talk about the distance in some reference frame between us and a distant galaxy and the galaxy is moving away okay but uh it's moving away and there is some effective apparent velocity that we can define. You know, at at any moment we have a Hubble constant which is a number and we have the distance and the formula from Hubble is that the apparent velocity is the Hubble constant times the distance, the apparent velocity to a galaxy. So whatever the universe is doing, there will be a distance so big that the Hubble constant times that distance is a apparent velocity greater than the speed of light. What is going on with that? It doesn't mean things are moving faster than the speed of light. The rule in general relativity is that two objects cannot pass by each other at a relative velocity faster than the speed of light. And us and a distant galaxy are not passing by each other. There is no uniquely well- defined velocity between two objects at different points in spaceime. You can only define velocity if the points are if the objects are literally next to each other. You can define quantities that have the units of velocity and act like a velocity and that's what we do in cosmology. So there's nothing different than what than what happens now versus what happens during inflation. Inflation is a case where as we were talking about before the second derivative of the scale factor is a positive number but the Hubble constant is still decreasing with time. There's the the statement that the universe is increasing faster than the speed of light, which is a statement that people sometimes make, is simply nonsense, is literally grammatically incorrect because the expansion rate of the universe is not a velocity. It does not have the units of velocity. It can't be greater than the speed of light. So, if anyone says and and very very smart people often say inflation is a kind of super luminal expansion, they don't mean that. They probably know better. uh don't listen to what they're saying and certainly don't worry about violating the speed of light limit.
